importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the Hamas-led attack on Israel that killed Sergeant Major Tal Haimi, marking the beginning of the conflict and the context for the hostage crisis.
The signing date of the US-proposed Gaza ceasefire deal, which set a timeline for the return of hostages and became central to diplomatic efforts.
The date of the identification and return of Sergeant Major Tal Haimi's body, representing a key milestone in the implementation of the ceasefire agreement.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period following the ceasefire agreement’s signing when diplomatic and military efforts focused on the return of deceased hostages, with delays and challenges leading to public and political pressure.

keyTakeAways: Sergeant Major Tal Haimi, a 41-year-old Israeli military official, was killed during the Hamas attack on October 7, 2023, while defending a kibbutz.
His body was identified by Israeli forensics and returned to Israel on October 20, 2025, making him the 13th deceased hostage to be transferred under the ceasefire agreement.
The ceasefire deal requires Hamas to return all deceased hostages within 72 hours, but Israeli intelligence believes Hamas may not be able to locate all bodies due to war damage in Gaza.
One previously handed-over body was found not to belong to an Israeli hostage, suggesting possible misidentification by Hamas, raising concerns about the accuracy of the return process.
The Trump administration has threatened to 'eradicate' Hamas if it violates the ceasefire, and US envoys have held high-level meetings with Israeli military leaders to oversee compliance.
The Hostages and Missing Families Forum expressed condolences to Haimi’s family, emphasizing the emotional relief of having his body returned after two years of uncertainty.
Israel has called on Hamas to return all deceased hostages, while also asserting that the ceasefire must be fulfilled 'one way or another.'

namedEntities.name: Tal Haimi
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is the deceased Israeli hostage whose body was identified and returned, representing a major step in the implementation of the ceasefire agreement and personal loss to Israeli families.

namedEntities.name: Hamas
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Hamas is the entity responsible for the initial attack and the subsequent handling of deceased hostages under the ceasefire deal, including alleged misidentification and delays in body returns.

namedEntities.name: Israel Defense Forces (IDF)
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The IDF is responsible for defending against Hamas attacks and enforcing the return of hostages under the ceasefire, including monitoring compliance and identifying remains.

namedEntities.name: US President Donald Trump
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Trump has publicly threatened to 'eradicate' Hamas if it violates the ceasefire, signaling strong US political and strategic pressure on Hamas to comply with the agreement.

namedEntities.name: Steve Witkoff
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Witkoff is a key architect of the ceasefire deal and has met with Israeli military officials to discuss implementation and compliance.

namedEntities.name: Jared Kushner
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Kushner, Trump’s son-in-law, participated in high-level meetings with Israeli generals to discuss ceasefire arrangements and hostage returns.

namedEntities.name: Knesset Speaker Amir Ohana
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He emphasized that the ceasefire, including the return of deceased hostages, must be fulfilled, reflecting political pressure within Israel.

namedEntities.name: Red Cross
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Red Cross facilitated the retrieval of the body from Gaza and transferred it to Israeli forces, playing a logistical role in the recovery process.

namedEntities.name: Thai national Sonthaya Oakkharasri
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She was the previous deceased hostage identified under the ceasefire agreement, providing context for the sequence of identifications and ongoing efforts.

namedEntities.name: Hostages and Missing Families Forum
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The group expressed condolences to Haimi’s family, highlighting public and emotional significance of the return of deceased hostages.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Israeli government has identified the remains of Sergeant Major Tal Haimi, a 41-year-old Israeli military official killed on October 7, 2023, during a Hamas-led attack on a kibbutz, as belonging to a deceased hostage. His body, retrieved by the Red Cross in Gaza and transferred to Israeli forces, was officially identified on October 20, 2025, marking him as the 13th deceased hostage to be returned under the US-proposed ceasefire deal signed on October 9, 2025. The return comes amid growing frustration and diplomatic tension over Hamas's inability to locate and return all deceased hostages, with Israeli intelligence suggesting destruction in Gaza makes this difficult. One previously handed-over body was found not to belong to an Israeli hostage, indicating potential misidentification. The Trump administration, through threats of 'eradication' of Hamas and high-level diplomatic meetings between US envoys and Israeli military leaders, continues to push for compliance with the ceasefire, including the return of all deceased hostages. The Hostages and Missing Families Forum has expressed deep condolences to Haimi’s family, underscoring the emotional significance of the body’s return after over two years of uncertainty.
title: Israel Identifies Body of Deceased Hostage as Sergeant Major Tal Haimi
